Tweets: No one wants to see businesses close, more people sickened and our economy further impacted. But our progress depends on cooperation and common sense. It’s the way both our citizens and our economy will stay healthy. 3/3

It is up to all of us to make a concerted effort to slow the spread of the virus. Right now, the health of our citizens and our economy depends upon everyone practicing good hygiene, social distancing and wearing a mask in public where social distancing isn’t possible. 2/3

Given the increase in the number of cases of COVID-19 we have seen in recent weeks, Wyoming has extended the public health orders currently in place through July 15. We've seen 288 new cases of COVID-19 in 15 counties in the past 2 weeks. 1/3

Happy Father's Day to all the fathers, grandfathers and men who are making a positive difference in a child's life. "Fatherhood is giving one’s all, from a child’s first day of life on, from the break of day to its end—on the job, in the household, but most of all, in the heart."
Some good economic news to report- Wyoming's May unemployment rate of 8.8% was the 3rd lowest in the country.
I'm holding a media briefing at 4pm today, June 16, to provide a COVID-19 update. Watch live on @WyomingPBS Facebook or YouTube.

Another round of thanks go out to Director General Alex Fan of @TECOinSeattle for facilitating Taiwan's donation of 10,000 N95 masks to Wyoming and the @WyoBizCouncil. We appreciate their continued support of our state's people and businesses.

...we are able to continue removing the few public health restrictions that remain. Our updated health orders allow Wyomingites to safely celebrate the 4th of July the way that all Americans should, with barbecues, parades and other celebrations of our nation’s independence. 5/5

It is my hope and desire that we do not see additional infections and cases of COVID-19 in Wyoming due to the recent protests. Wyoming will carefully monitor the rate of infection over the next few weeks. We have made outstanding progress and I remain hopeful...4/5

However, large gatherings of people do involve significant health risks, and this risk has been identified both locally and nationally. I encourage those who chose to participate in peaceful protests to practice social distancing and wear face coverings as much as possible. 3/5

This is America and everyone has a right to express their point of view. I have not encouraged any actions by law enforcement to cite protesters for violating the state's health orders, as I recognize the importance of the ability to protest, both for Wyoming and our Nation. 2/5

It’s refreshing to see citizens feeling free to express their First Amendment rights, as we have seen so often over the past month. I respect the right, and appreciate the intent of all those who have spoken out, even if it is against decisions I have made. 1/5

Our COVID-19 dashboard has been updated to reflect the improvement in the statewide metrics used to ease restrictions. It is important to remain vigilant, but with our continued success, I am confident we can continue lifting the very few remaining public health restrictions. 2/2

Wyoming's updated public health orders that take effect June 15 will allow indoor gatherings of up to 250 people with social distancing restrictions, permit parades and allow our K-12 schools to resume in-person instruction for all students. 1/2

It was a pleasure to visit with World War II veteran Sidney Walton, 101, this morning at the Capitol and thank him for his service. Mr. Walton joined the army in 1941 and served in the 34th Infantry, 8th Division.
On this day in 1944, Allied troops stormed the beach in Normandy and changed the course of World War II. Today we remember their bravery and honor their sacrifice. #DDay

I will hold a media briefing at 3 pm today, June 4, to provide updates on COVID-19 and the state's budget.
Watch live on @WyomingPBS TV, Facebook and here:

The Wyoming Emergency Housing Assistance Program is now accepting applications. This eviction prevention program serves eligible Wyoming residents who lack sufficient income or resources to pay housing costs.
Information here:

I would like to provide some additional clarification surrounding yesterday’s announcement that six of Wyoming’s signature rodeo events will not be taking place this summer. My statement can be viewed here:

I'm holding a media briefing at 3 pm today, May 27, to provide a COVID-19 update and discuss the status of large events in Wyoming this summer. Watch live on @WyomingPBS television, Facebook and YouTube.
On Memorial Day we honor those who made the ultimate sacrifice serving their country and defending the freedoms we enjoy today.

As we enter Memorial Day weekend, have fun but enjoy yourselves responsibly. Wear a face covering if you're going to come into close contact with others. It's a sign of respect for your neighbors and the vulnerable.

Under our new plan, WY will conduct COVID-19 testing at long-term care facilities. We will be test a % of all residents & staff at each facility; Where there is a confirmed case, all staff & residents will be tested weekly. Early interventions are critical to limiting outbreaks.

Congratulations to Megan Dufault of Jackson and Sam Miller of Laramie who were named @usedgov Presidential Scholars. This honor places them among the  most distinguished graduating high school seniors in the country.
Staying safe during COVID-19 shouldn't mean sacrificing the health of your children. Well child visits are still critical, and healthcare providers have adapted to ensure patient safety.

I want to thank the Legislature for their work in passing these bills. This is an unprecedented time, and while there is more work to be done, Wyoming and America’s unsinkable economy is coming out of hibernation. 4/4

We have also developed an eviction prevention program for eligible renters and homeowners who have been financially impacted by COVID-19. It will be administered by the Wyoming Community Development Authority which will begin accepting applications soon. 3/4

and provide support to cities, towns, counties and tribal communities. They also create three relief programs that will provide grant assistance to our state’s businesses impacted by the pandemic. The @WyoBizCouncil will begin accepting applications for these in early June. 2/4

Yesterday I signed three bills that provide a framework for spending the $1.25 billion in federal funding Wyoming received through the CARES Act. These bills will help Wyoming expand COVID-19 testing, fund economic development projects.... 1/4

I'm holding a briefing at 3pm today, May 20, to provide an update on COVID-19 in Wyoming and talk about the 3 bills passed by the Legislature during the recent special session. Watch online at @WyomingPBS TV, Facebook and Youtube.

I'm happy to report that roads, hiking trails, and rock climbing routes at Devil's Tower National Monument will reopen to public access on May 22. Visitors should be prepared for limited services and avoid crowding. The Visitor Center will remain closed at this time.

The recent death of a member of the Northern Arapaho tribe and the two additional deaths recently identified are sad reminders of the serious, ongoing impact of COVID-19. My thoughts are with their. families. We must continue our efforts to minimize the spread of this virus.

Congratulations to Jeff Makelky, Principal of Big Piney High School who has been named the 2020 State Principal of the Year by the Wyoming Association of Secondary School Principals. Thank you for creating a positive school culture and helping to ensure every student succeeds.

We have eased our restrictions to allow gatherings of 25 persons or fewer. Church services are exempt from this limit, but social distancing is required between household groups. Stay safe as you worship.

I want to thank the Wyoming Legislature for their diligence during this historic special session. The bills that they passed will provide relief to Wyoming workers, businesses, families and communities. We will continue to work cooperatively to serve the citizens of our state.

On #ArmedForcesDay we recognize and celebrate each of the branches of the U.S. military. I thank all of the men and women serving our country, as well as their families, for their service and their sacrifice.
Looking for more data about COVID-19 in your county? The Health Department has county-specific dashboards to help you better understand what's happening with the virus where you live. Visit

Face coverings can help slow the spread of COVID-19 and help prevent those who may not know they have the virus from transmitting it to others. I encourage everyone to wear one when social distancing is not possible. It's a courtesy to protect your neighbors and your community.
Keep an eye out for our @wyoguard C-130s around the state today honoring our first responders and medical professionals. Estimated flyover times can be found here:

I have ordered all US and Wyoming flags to be lowered to half-staff statewide from sunrise to sunset on Friday, May 15, 2020 in observance of National Peace Officers Memorial Day. This day recognizes members of law enforcement who died or were injured in the line of duty.

I would like to clarify a point of confusion in the updated public health orders taking effect May 15. Movie theaters and performance venues may operate with more than 25 persons in attendance, by adhering to social distancing guidelines and restrictions listed in Order 1.

I will be holding a media briefing at 3 pm today, May 13 to discuss updated public health orders, COVID-19 testing and the special session. I will be joined by @EdBuchananWyo who will provide an update on the 2020 election season. Watch live on @WyomingPBS Youtube and Facebook.

The phased reopenings of @YellowstoneNPS and @GrandTetonNPS will help safely reawaken Wyoming’s tourism industry and get America’s economy up and going again. Their  plans, developed with local input, will help protect employees, visitors and neighboring communities

This is #NationalPoliceWeek, a week when we celebrate the bravery and selflessness of law enforcement officers who keep our communities safe. I want to thank our local, state and federal officers for their service to the people of Wyoming.
I want to wish all the moms and grandmothers across Wyoming a Happy Mother's Day. Mothers teach us patience, kindness, and how to love unconditionally. We should recognize all they do every day.

Wyoming counties and our public health laboratory currently have adequate supplies to expand testing. Please don’t avoid testing out of fear. By identifying cases, we can help control outbreaks and prevent community spread. That’s good for all of us.

Most Wyoming counties have now received variances from our current public health orders. This flexibility comes with responsibility-- practice social distancing and adhere to the guidance businesses are putting in place. This is how we will stay healthy and reawaken our economy.

We will be sharing additional details on the next phase of Wyoming's transition at a media briefing at 3pm today, which will be streamed live on @WyomingPBS Facebook and Youtube. In the meantime, remember that most Wyoming businesses can operate without restrictions.

Wyoming counties and our Department of Health continue to work quickly to grant variances to our public health orders where appropriate based on local data. We will continue to updated this graphic as additional county-level variances are granted.

It’s #NationalNursesDay and I want to express my appreciation to all Wyoming nurses and healthcare workers for their tireless commitment throughout this pandemic. Thank you for going above and beyond during this unprecedented time to serve our communities and protect lives.

Today is the National Day of Awareness for Missing and Murdered Indigenous Women and Girls. I am proud of the efforts Wyoming has made to address this issue, including the passage of legislation to improve data collection and implement an Amber Alert system for our tribes.

As Wyoming’s state public health orders are eased, variances have been granted to some counties based on local health data. The Department of Health is continuing to review additional requests. More details here:

I signed a proclamation and flexed today in honor of Teacher Appreciation Week. Our Wyoming teachers have shown tremendous flexibility and dedication to educating our youth during this challenging time. Every one of them is making a difference. #TeacherAppreciationWeek

The @CDCgov conducted a special testing study of 46 patients and 172 staff members at the Wyoming State Hospital in Evanston and found no new cases of COVID-19. Kudos to our WSH hospital staff for their vigilance.

This program, which is part of the CARES Act, provides up to 39 weeks of Unemployment Insurance benefits for those who are self-employed, independent contractors, gig economy workers, those who have exhausted their regular and extended benefits and others.

May is Mental Health Awareness Month. During these challenging times, it's important to prioritize your mental health, recognize that you are not alone, and offer support to others living with mental health conditions. #MentalHealthAwarenessMonth

Wyoming's new public health orders go into effect today as we ease some of our restrictions. Operations of personal service businesses, gyms and childcare centers will be different during this time. I want to thank our businesses for adapting as we work to keep our citizens safe

We reported 8 new cases of COVID-19 today. Nearly two-thirds of the state's confirmed cases have fully recovered. The 14-day self-quarantine directive will now expire on May 8 and camping at State Parks campgrounds will begin to open on May 15 for Wyoming residents only.

I will be holding a media briefing at 4 pm today, April 28, to provide an update on modified orders allowing gyms, barber shops, hair salons and other personal care services to reopen May 1. Watch live on @WyomingPBS TV, YouTube and Facebook.

The next round of federal Paycheck Protection Program funding is now available. I urge all small businesses to work with their local lenders and apply for these @SBAgov loans as quickly as possible. Visit  for additional information
As we begin to modify some of our public health orders, it's important to remember there will be a new "normal".  #NewNormal

Congratulations to @wyo_football players @ljw21 and @cassh7mula who were selected in the @NFL draft by the @Bengals and @Patriots respectively. Congrats as well to @TyHall_ who signed with the @AtlantaFalcons. I know you’ll all represent Wyoming well.

The health of our communities must come first as we look to ease restrictions. We are eager to invigorate our economy, but we are taking a measured approach. Everything won't reopen immediately and social distancing remains important as we take the next steps.

Wyoming is relying on six metrics to guide our transition towards easing restrictions.  As I’ve said many times before– our transition will be gradual with incremental steps. Our goal is to minimize public health risks and prevent clusters of new cases.

We saw a spike in confirmed cases today in Fremont County. With additional supplies, the state's public health lab has expanded testing. Remember to wear a mask for the protection of others– COVID-19 can be transmitted even when you are not showing symptoms.

I recognize Wyomingites' desire to get back to work. But Mr. Hurt's story is a reminder of why our orders were put in place.
"You have to take it very serious, because I guarantee you don’t want to be in a situation I was in, or feel the way I do now."

I want to thank Director General Alex Fan of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) for the donation of 50,000 medical face masks from Taiwan to Wyoming. We will be distributing those masks soon to where they are needed most.
I will be holding a media briefing at 3 pm today, April 23, to discuss the state's response to COVID-19 and plans going forward. Watch live on @WyomingPBS Facebook, YouTube and television.

Today marks the 50th anniversary of Earth Day, and Wyoming has a lot to celebrate. We must continue to support responsible stewardship of our natural resources and protect the health of our state's wild lands and open spaces.
I joined @TeamCavuto today on @FoxNews to talk about the plunge in oil prices and Wyoming’s COVID-19 response.

Data reviewed today by the Wyoming Department of Health revealed some duplication in counting the number of tests completed and we have adjusted that number. Our hearts go out to the family in Fremont County that lost loved ones yesterday to this deadly disease. #StayHomeStaySafe

3/3 I continue to communicate regularly with Tribal leadership regarding both State and tribal strategies for handling the mounting challenges posed by COVID-19.  The Tribes and State must coordinate our response for the health of Wyoming citizens, as we are all in this together.

2/3 as both the Northern Arapaho and Eastern Shoshone Tribes took advanced protective measures early on, including an aggressive testing strategy. I want to commend each of the sovereign nations for taking those early steps for the safety of Wind River Reservation communities.

1/3 I want to extend my condolences to the Northern Arapaho Tribe and to the families of the four individuals that passed away last night due to COVID-19. These deaths highlight the insidious nature of the illness,

We all want our businesses and workers to be able to thrive again. But, we must be deliberate about our process. COVID-19 can spread easily, even among people without symptoms. We are working on a plan to transition Wyoming, but social distancing must continue. #SlowTheSpread

I appreciate hearing these voices and I want all our citizens to know it was not an easy decision to put our public health orders in place. I recognize the incredible impact these orders have had on our state’s businesses and workers.

We will continue to prioritize the health and well being of our residents and will take a measured approach to easing the restrictions in place. n the coming days we will release more information about the metrics we will use to forward and get our economy rolling again.

I met with protesters who came to the Capitol today to exercise their 1st Amendment rights to demonstrate and urge that we “reopen” Wyoming. While I disagree with their choice to violate a public health order, I nonetheless thought it was important to listen to their concerns.

While Wyoming was never shut down, our ability to transition to a new phase is dependent upon on the actions each of us takes. Maintain your social distancing efforts and limit your trips. Models suggest our peak has not arrived. #StaySafeStayHome
Our rural hospitals are critical to Wyoming communities and our state's economy. COVID-19 has put them under additional stress.
If the people of Wyoming continue to do the right thing, we can begin a transition. We are now developing a plan for that transition phase. Read the full press release here:

To protect our citizens’ health, these orders will remain in effect through April 30. The transition into a new phase of recovery must be health data-driven, not date driven. What we do in the coming weeks will determine the way we can ease these orders and rekindle our economy

I want to thank the people of Wyoming for their work in flattening the curve, and I also want to reiterate that we are, and have been, open for business. Our existing statewide orders are consistent with Phase One of @realDonaldTrump  Guidelines for Opening Up America Again.
Limiting outings is important. The more places you go, the greater opportunity there is for COVID-19 to spread. When you have to go out, only do so for essentials. #SlowTheSpread

Today we learned of the 2nd COVID-19 related death in Wyoming. As of today, there are 19 reported hospitalizations statewide for COVID-19. As we consider our steps moving forward, we will continue to use data to inform our decisions. #StayHomeStaySafe

I'll be holding a media briefing at 4 p.m. today, April 15 to provide an update on Wyoming’s ongoing response to the COVID-19 pandemic. It can be viewed live on Wyoming PBS TV, their Facebook page and YouTube channel.

Our case numbers continue to rise. All communities - even those with a handful of confirmed cases - must remain diligent with social distancing and stay the course to #SlowTheSpread and make a difference in our future.

Wyoming's first death related to COVID-19 was reported today along with 5 new cases. We must continue to be vigilant about following public health guidance and social distancing, particularly because this disease is so dangerous to those who are most vulnerable. #StaySafeStayHome

Today we honor the lineworkers who work 24-hours a day, 7-days a week to make sure we have power to our homes, businesses and hospitals. They put their lives on the line and work in harsh conditions to make sure we have this public utility. Thank you for your work.

...and sadly serves as a grim reminder of the importance of following public health orders and guidance so we can reduce the number of serious illnesses and deaths in our state. Jennie and I extend our thoughts and prayers to this gentleman’s family and friends.

I am saddened to learn that we have lost our first Wyoming citizen to COVID-19, a Johnson County man with underlying health conditions that put him at higher risk of severe illness and complications related to the virus.  This one was close to home... 1/2

While several states reported some positive news during this morning's Governor's call with @VP, the importance of social distancing measures was reinforced- particularly for those with underlying health conditions. It's critical we stay the course. #StaySafeStayHome

We have confirmed 70 new cases of COVID-19 in Wyoming in the past 7 days, and there are now confirmed cases in all but two Wyoming counties. Remember, the "recovered" number in parenthesis on this map includes probable cases that have recovered. More data:
In these uncertain times, may the miracle of Easter bring you renewed hope, love and joy. Jennie and I wish each of you and your families a safe and blessed holiday.

Teton and Laramie counties continue to have the largest number of confirmed COVID-19 cases. Stay safe tomorrow—a spring snowstorm should make it easy to choose to stay home and celebrate with family. Wyoming, your efforts are making a difference. Thank you.

This graphic offers basic info; Visit the Wyoming Department of Health website for data on demographics like age and gender of those diagnosed, along with the most common symptoms in confirmed positive cases. #StayHomeStaySafe this holiday weekend.

I had a great call with Dr. Anthony Fauci this morning. We discussed the potential for antibody testing and the need for Wyoming to have access to additional diagnostic testing materials. Dr. Fauci also praised the actions we have taken to date to #SlowtheSpread.

I have signed a proclamation declaring today a Day of Prayer in Response to the COVID-19 Pandemic. Across all faiths and beliefs, we can all come together at this time of year to find a sense of peace and purpose. #DayOfPrayer
#StayHomeStaySafe

As more test results return, we are learning more about how COVID-19 is spreading in Wyoming. We may have fewer confirmed cases than other states, but the illness caused by this virus is serious. A few cases in a small community can cause devastating impacts. #StayHomeStaySafe

Wyoming's unemployment compensation fund is the healthiest in the country. Our tradition of fiscal responsibility means we will be able to continue to provide assistance to our workers when they need it most.

We have added data on Probable Cases. These include a total count of people who are a close contact to a laboratory confirmed COVID-19  case AND develop symptoms, but are not tested. This count includes probable cases that have recovered. More data here:

I'm holding a media briefing at 1 p.m. today, April 8, to provide updates on COVID-19 in Wyoming and the resources available to help workers and businesses. You can watch live on my Facebook page, Wyoming PBS television and .

We have now added recovered cases in each county along with the total number of confirmed positive cases.  For those seeking more information, additional data is available on the Wyoming Health Department's COVID-19 webpage. #StayHomeStaySafe

We will be adding additional information to this overview in the near future. Remember that testing supplies remain limited and this is not a complete picture of the presence of COVID-19 statewide. #StayHomeStaySafe

The Wyoming Department of Health is supporting a CDC recommendation to wear cloth face coverings if you need to go out in the community in order to help slow the spread of COVID-19. This is not a replacement for social distancing. Guidelines here:

Our Unemployment Office is working quickly to implement expanded benefits available under the CARES Act. These include an extension of regular unemployment, additional funding for those eligible, and the expansion of benefits for self-employed or contract employees.

Wyoming recorded it's 200th confirmed case of COVID-19 today, but we know that there are many more untested Wyomingites who have the virus. Keep yourself and your family safe and our healthcare workers protected by staying home and social distancing. #StayHomeStayHealthy
The First Lady and I want you to know what we're doing to keep our people safe and our communities functioning as best they can during these challenging times.
Lincoln County has its first confirmed case. With warming temperatures this weekend, it's important to remember to stay vigilant and keep your distance as you enjoy some fresh air. #staysafe
Now is not the time to travel to Wyoming. We are focused on protect the health of our citizens and the resources of our rural healthcare facilities. Stay home and stay safe.

I have also issued a directive requiring any individual coming to Wyoming for a non-work-related purpose to immediately self-quarantine for 14 days. Visitors from neighboring states have strained the resources of our communities and put public health at risk.

I have extended the three existing statewide health orders through April 30 to slow community transmission of COVID-19. I want to be perfectly clear- we want all Wyoming residents to stay at home. Our focus is on improving compliance and adherence. That is how we will save lives.

At 3 p.m. today, April 3, I am holding a press conference to provide an update on Wyoming's response to COVID-19 and outline what we are doing next to keep Wyomingites safe. You can watch here on Facebook or on Youtube at .

We continue to monitor the spread of COVID-19 closely and now have confirmed cases in 16 Wyoming counties as well as additional recovered cases. By staying home and avoiding gatherings, we can #SlowTheSpread and save lives.

Please note, the number of tests does not include all negative results from private laboratories. COVID-19 will continue to spread and doesn't discriminate according to age or overall health. But we know staying home and social distancing will help #SlowTheSpread

I signed a proclamation declaring today #CensusDay Now more than ever, it's critical that each of us in Wyoming is counted. Census results help determine how billions of dollars in funding flow into Wyoming communities each year. .

It's #CensusDay2020! While staying at home today, I encourage each of you to respond and ensure we get an accurate count. 
Census results help determine how billions of dollars in federal funding flow into Wyoming communities each year.

As we see more confirmed cases, its critical we continue to limit public contact as much as possible. Your actions don't just impact you, they impact the people around you.  Thank you to all Wyomingites who are doing your part. #StayHomeStaySafe
I took questions and heard your concerns about #COVID19 during an @AARPWY TeleTown Hall today.  I'm grateful that so many of our state's older residents are so engaged on this critical issue.
▶️We have updated info on  including an FAQ for Wyoming citizens and additional links to resources developed from our 5 COVID-19 task forces. #StayHome
We will continue to closely monitor the operations of our state parks to ensure visitor safety, and may take additional action if our health officials deem it necessary.

#COVID19 case numbers have tripled in a week, a result of both increased testing and increased disease. The public health orders and social distancing measures we've put in place will help, if they are followed. It's up to you Wyoming- together, we can #slowthespread
In an hour (3:30 pm), I will hold a media briefing to provide updates on Wyoming's #COVID19 response. Watch live on the @WyomingPBS Facebook page or on YouTube
Thank you to these volunteers and others around the state who are stepping up to support our healthcare workers.

Additional collection kits were distributed last week, but testing is still limited nationally and in Wyoming. It's important for Wyomingites to understand this is not a complete picture of the prevalence of COVID-19 in our state. Stay safe, stay home, practice #SocialDistancing

It's critical we limit person-to-person contact over the coming weeks. Extended families need to practice #socialdistancing as well. Delay gatherings with extended family. If you are delivering food or supplies to loved ones, you can protect them by staying 6 feet apart.
The First Lady and I want to talk with you about how social distancing and staying home is going to help save lives. We're all in this together, Wyoming.

We are continuing to see more test results return and a corresponding rise in the number of confirmed cases. Help #SlowTheSpread  by staying home whenever possible. For county-by-county statistics visit

This is how we can save lives and protect people’s health.  I also understand the ongoing strain these measures are having on businesses, workers and Wyoming communities but it is critical each of us takes these steps now.

I am extending the three statewide health orders through April 17 to #slowthespread of community transmission of COVID-19. It is imperative we all respond to this public health crisis by staying home whenever possible and practicing proper social distancing when they must go out.

The number of counties with confirmed cases has increased, a reminder that COVID-19 will impact all of us. Staying home whenever possible is the best way to #SlowTheSpread We have added data on recovered cases to this graphic.

Grocery stores are an essential service that won't close. Keep in mind, #socialdistancing matters when shopping, too. Give your neighbors space and don't go out if you are sick. Actions like these help #slowthespread. #COVID19WY
I applaud this decision, as well as the cooperation of the utility companies, for working together to help Wyoming's people during this difficult time.

As our state's testing capacity expands and more results come in from commercial labs, we expect confirmed cases to rise. The steps we are urging all Wyomingites to take– staying home and practicing social distancing – are what will help mitigate the impacts in the weeks to come.

Now is not the time to be evicting individuals who may have recently become unemployed. It’s important for us all to work together and support one-another during these difficult times. If you are struggling, Wyoming 211 has a list of statewide resources.

I have been contacted by many constituents who are concerned that they may be facing eviction proceedings as the end of the month approaches. I urge our state’s landlords to exercise maximum flexibility with your tenants when it comes to rent payments.

I urge our citizens to stay home whenever possible and go out only when absolutely necessary. This will help Wyoming #SlowtheSpread of COVID-19 and #FlattenTheCurve Your voluntary actions and discipline will make the difference for you, your family and your neighbors. #COVID19WY

The number of confirmed cases continues to grow. Tomorrow, March 24 at 1 p.m. I will be joined by the First Lady and state leaders to share how we can work together to help one another and #SlowTheSpread Watch live on the @WyomingPBS  Facebook page and YouTube channel. #COVID19WY

I understand the impact of these measures and sympathize with those most affected, especially small business owners, but this is about saving lives. We have tried to navigate a thoughtful course, but as COVID-19 spreads through our communities, we must take this action now.

Wyoming is taking further steps to #slowthespread of #COVID19WY. Today, we issued an order to temporarily close nail salons; hair salons; barber shops; massage parlors; tattoo, body art, piercing shops; and cosmetology, electrology, and esthetic services until April 3.

Helping your neighbor is the WY way. WY distilleries are banding together to make hand sanitizer to help #slowthespread of #COVID19.  Supplies for these innovative efforts are paid for through Imminent Threat Grants from the @WyoBizCouncil

We have confirmed two additional cases of COVID-19 in the state today. Viruses don't respect county boundaries- the best way to #SlowTheSpread is staying home whenever possible, working from home if it's feasible and limiting our trips out. #COVID19WY

We are at a critical time for our state. There are unquestionably more cases out there. Thank you to all Wyomingites who are practicing social distancing. 
Limit travel and stay home if possible. 
Wash hands frequently. #COVID19WY
Testing will continue to expand statewide, so we can expect the number of confirmed cases to increase. Please practice good hygiene and social distancing measures to #SlowTheSpread #COVID19WY

9/9 Shop for groceries if you need to, get food delivered from your favorite restaurant, support your local business with a gift card purchase. But please practice social distancing measures during this critical time. #COVID19WY

8/9 By limiting travel and face-to-face contact now, we reduce the potential to overwhelm our rural healthcare facilities and cause unnecessary deaths ahead. Wyoming’s rural nature does not protect us from impacts.
7/9 Like the rest of America, Wyoming’s access to testing supplies is limited. Our best tool right now for slowing the spread of this disease is practicing social distancing measures.

6/9 ...the enormity of the public health challenge facing us and respond to it. COVID-19 may seem far away, but it is here. Our neighboring states are all experiencing the same escalation in the number of positive cases as we are.

5/9 I am a businessman and understand full well what the consequences would be of closures. I know that the worst impacts would fall on those least able to absorb it.   As confirmed cases have grown from 1 to 23 in a week, spanning 8 counties, we should be honest about...

4/9 ...that unemployment benefits are readily accessible, that those who are food insecure are fed, and that our essential business functions are preserved. I am proud of my Wyoming heritage and the fact that we can serve as a beacon for our nation.

3/9 We are in this for the long haul and we will emerge stronger for this test, and I will always be guided by my concern for the health and safety of the people of Wyoming. folks at the state are working 24/7 to assure that proper supplies arrive as quickly as possible...

2/9 From the beginning, I have emphasized that the challenge we are facing represents two threats: disease and economic harm.  I have been very clear that both are important.  I believe firmly we must do the right thing, do it right away, and do it the right way.

1/9 The coronavirus is the most disruptive thing that most of us have ever seen.  I recognize and appreciate the criticism from some that we have not acted rapidly, and I appreciate and recognize the criticism that we have acted too much. #COVID19WY

Excellent news: Wyoming small businesses impacted by COVID-19 have received final Federal approval to seek loans up to $2 million as part of the SBA’s Economic Injury Disaster Loan program. To apply visit:  #COVID19WY
We are a state filled with helpers.
If you weren't able to watch last night's fireside chat with the First Lady on Facebook, a recording has been posted on my website.

Yesterday's closure order only impacts certain types of businesses. Included in the list are restaurants, bars, gyms, movie theaters, music halls and day cares. Other private businesses are not required to close. Social distancing is our best weapon to #StopTheSpread #COVID19WY

I have been asked to provide clarification of the statewide order issued today by the State Health Officer. A copy of the order is posted on my website. County Health Officers can also provide additional information.
The First Lady will be joining me for a Facebook Live broadcast at 6:30 pm tonight, March 19, to discuss COVID-19 and its impact to our state. Please join us.

I have endorsed an order from our state health officer closing public places for a period of 2 weeks to help slow the spread of COVID-19. It is a critical step for protecting public health and the health of our most vulnerable residents.

It's time for Wyomingites to do all we can to slow the spread of COVID-19 in the state. Following the @POTUS social distancing guidelines will benefit all of us, particularly our health care providers and vulnerable populations. #covid19WY
We've launched a state website to provide resources and information on the COVID-19 pandemic,  Do your part to mitigate the impacts. #COVID19WY
We can all help protect one another and alleviate the strain on our medical facilities. #COVID19WY
4/4 ...avoid overwhelming our healthcare system and support those most in need. Wyoming will emerge from this crisis strong and proud of how we met these challenges facing all of us.

3/4 Although absolutely necessary, I recognize the toll these measures will take on those most dependent on a working wage. But by working together and practicing good hygiene, kindness and charity, we can keep vulnerable adults healthy...

2/4 We should use good judgment, avoid unnecessary travel, keep social gatherings to groups of fewer than 10 people, and use drive-through, pickup or delivery options from our local restaurants. These are going to be perhaps the toughest times any of us will see in our lifetimes.

1/4 Today, in consultation with our State Health Officer, I am supporting the #coronavirus  Guidelines President Trump has issued for America. Accordingly, over the next 15 days, I ask that we do all we can as Wyomingites to help slow the spread of COVID-19 in our state.
Visit  and click on the COVID-19 tab in the upper left for information and links related to the COVID-19 outbreak. We expect to issue additional recommendations from our office later today.
I will host a press conference at 3:30 today to provide an update on Wyoming’s planning and response to the COVID-19 pandemic. It will be streamed on my Facebook page:

This is Wyoming, where we are all neighbors. While social distancing should be a priority, it should not keep us from helping one another out. I am thinking of our first responders and healthcare workers  who may be without child care. This is a time to help one another out.
This is an attempt to allow schools and communities to prepare to operate in a way that mitigates community spread of COVID-19 and minimizes negative economic impacts locally and statewide.

In conjuction with @jillian4supt i have recommended that all schools remain closed to students through at least April 3. Local superintendents and school boards will make the final decisions on closures.

Please know that close coordination is ongoing between the Department of Health, Office of Homeland Security and my office. Our response is based on the best available information, and we will be continually adjusting to what is a rapidly changing situation.

In response, our state health officer has issued recommendations for assisted living facilities that match restrictive guidelines the federal government has issued for nursing homes. These include no visitors or non-essential healthcare personnel.

Initial follow-up with this individual indicated potential community spread of this virus in the Lander area. Wyoming Department of Health staff will be available to consult as local officials consider decisions about public events and other community-related activities.

I want to provide some updated information on the Fremont County case of #COVIDー19 that was identified yesterday. The patient is hospitalized at SageWest Health Care in Lander and is a resident of Showboat Retirement Center in Lander.

Wyoming has confirmed the second known case of COVID-19 in the state. The patient is a hospitalized older adult male Fremont County resident with currently unknown exposure risk. We will be sharing additional information as it becomes available.
I will be hosting a press conference on the states response to the first COVID-19 case. It will be streamed on my Facebook page.

The current risk of transmission in Wyoming remains low for most residents. Our Health Department is following up to learn more details about the person’s exposure risk and to identify anyone who may have been in close contact with the patient.

Our state has been planning for this situation for weeks and we will continue our coordinated efforts to address this threat. We will continue to work closely with our state agencies, federal partners and local officials to implement all necessary steps to protect public health.

Our state health lab has identified the first known case of a state resident with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19). The individual is an adult female from Sheridan County with some recent domestic travel history.

Older adults and those with underlying chronic illnesses are most at risk of severe COVID-19 illness. Wyoming is continuing to prepare and working to protect public health in the event cases appear within our state. For more information, visit

Earlier today I joined the nations governors and @VP for a weekly phone call to hear the latest updates from the @CDCgov . While Wyoming still has no confirmed cases of COVID-19 it’s likely the disease will spread to our state at some point. We are preparing for that likelihood.

This afternoon I joined Wyoming Dept. of Health officials for a conference call with long term care and nursing facilities to ensure proper protocols and preventative measures are in place to protect residents of these facilities from #coronavirus.
On #InternationalWomensDay2020 we should both celebrate women's achievements and remember our shared responsibility to support equal opportunities for all women.

It was my pleasure to welcome @rbalsaud,Saudi Arabia’s ambassador to the United States to the Capitol. The discussion with Princess Reema, legislators and state leaders touched on tourism, economic diversification and workforce issues.
This is a true honor. Public-private partnerships are critical to achieving breakthroughs in clean energy.
Congratulations! It’s been a tough season but our Cowboys have shown grit and determination. #OneWyoming

I was proud to sign the first bills of the 2020 legislative session this afternoon. These bills increase penalties for human trafficking,  help struggling kids have the opportunity to remain with their families, and fund the fight against terrestrial invasive species.
A short tutorial on handwashing, a simple, important step to help prevent viral respiratory illnesses.

I'm pleased to welcome Ed Seidel as the new University of Wyoming president. Ed has demonstrated visionary leadership and brings a strong focus on economic development. His exceptional technical and scientific background will benefit the research efforts at UW.

I-80 across much of Wyoming will remain closed in both directions for at least another 24 hours as cleanup continues from crashes yesterday that involved more than 100 vehicles. If you are planning travel across the state, please use alternate routes.
Thanks to @TomBurman1 for presenting me with a game ball from the @novaAZBOWL. What a great experience this was for our Cowboys players and fans. #OneWyoming #GoWyo
Congratulations to Kate MacGregor. We are fortunate to have another leader @Interior who is well-versed in issues surrounding energy development, wildlife, water and other natural resources”

The Wyoming Department of Health continues to closely monitor the #coronavirus outbreak and is coordinating with local and federal officials. There are no reported cases in Wyoming at this time. More info here:
The students from Mrs. Barkee's 4th grade class at Cheyenne's Alta Vista Elementary School incorporated some wonderful Wyoming imagery in their Thank You card. I had a great time talking with them.

In Wyoming you never know who's going to stop by the Capitol. Thank you to @RepLizCheney and @SenatorEnzi for saying hello when Jennie and I were chatting with the Wyoming Federation of Republican Women.

Today, I sent the acting superintendent of @GrandTetonNPS a letter condemning the aerial culling of mountain goats in Grand Teton National Park. This removal method has also been opposed by the Wyoming Game & Fish Commission.
I had a great conversation with first-year students in the WWAMI program, which is Wyoming's medical school. These future physicians are committed to Wyoming and improving healthcare in our state.

Students participating in FCCLA, FBLA and FFA spoke eloquently about the importance of #CTE during today's proclamation signing. They were an inspiring group who will help lead our state into the future.

Thank you to the Wyoming Women's Foundation for inviting me to celebrate the release of the 2020 Self-Sufficiency Standard. This study looks at what it actually costs to raise a family in Wyoming. Understanding the underlying challenges will help drive better policy.
SF 138 and its companion bill HB 249 are only the first steps in a thorough process that would allow the state to evaluate this purchase.

I want to ensure our leadership gives this potential investment due diligence and determines if this would provide a return on investment to benefit Wyoming citizens. Our state faces big challenges in the years to come, ones that will require equally big solutions and ideas.

I was joined by Senate President @S29Perkins and House Speaker @SteveHarshman today to express our support for two bills that could return Wyoming lands to Wyoming people and potentially generate significant income for our state.

On President's Day we honor the great leaders who helped shape our democracy.
“Truth will ultimately prevail where there is pains to bring it to light.” – George Washington #PresidentsDay

I'm happy to announce the signing of my Migration Corridor Executive Order. This was a collaborative process that shows how Wyoming can come together on difficult issues, solve problems together, and develop a Wyoming solution.

Thank you to @DavoDenniston for your inspiring words this morning at the Governor's Prayer Breakfast. Your determination and dedication are admirable, and you are an incredible asset to our University.
Thank you to @AjitPaiFCC for joining us for a roundtable discussion about the importance of rural broadband expansion to Wyoming.
I will deliver my 2020 State of the State address to a Joint Session of the Wyoming Legislature at 10 am on Monday. The speech may be viewed here:
I had a wonderful conversation with Craig Blumenshine on a wide range of topics for "Capitol Outlook" today. The interview will air on @WyomingPBS at 7:30 pm on Friday.
At this time, no reported or suspected cases of Novel Coronavirus have been identified in Wyoming and the risk to Wyoming residents from this virus remains low.
Please drive carefully today if you're headed out and watch out for plow trucks. Roads are slick around the state.
The Governor's Invasive Species Initiative will meet on Monday, February 3 in Casper. Terrestrial invasive species are a significant threat to Wyoming’s forests, rangelands and agricultural lands.
Today @POTUS signed the #USMCA trade agreement. With Canada being Wyoming's largest export market, this deal is a win for Wyoming farmers, ranchers and businesses.

I'll be hosting listening sessions in Rawlins, Pinedale, Kemmerer and Rock Springs on Saturday, Feb. 1, to engage with citizens and local officials about my Migration Corridor Executive Order. We can both protect wildlife and support our economy.

Today is International Holocaust Remembrance Day and the 75th anniversary of the liberation of the Auschwitz. May we never forget. 
"For the dead and the living we must bear witness." Elie Wiesel
Great to meet barrel racer extraordinaire @PedoneRyann at the @NationalWestern stock show today.

Thanks to Pine Bluffs Elementary School for hosting @jillian4supt and I last night during your Hour of Code event. Computer science is part of the core knowledge and skills that young students will employ for a lifetime.

The ports of the United States of America are for all the commerce of the United States of America. We stand today to ensure reasonable access to that foreign trade for all of Wyoming’s and Montana’s products and those of the other states without access to ports.

A de facto blockade limiting the citizens of any state to participate in interstate and international commerce cannot be arbitrarily imposed by another. Congress has the sole authority to regulate trade.

This is an effort to protect all the rights of states as guaranteed under the Constitution -- all rights including those that pertain to commerce.  It is neither a political battle nor an attempt to ride roughshod over the legitimate rights of states to manage their own affairs

Our Constitution was written to ensure that interior states have access to foreign markets through our coastal sister states. Today we are defending Wyoming’s and Montana’s right to utilize American port and rail infrastructure for its products.
I did not make this decision rashly or lightly– vital state and economic interests are at stake. This case is about the right of states to conduct commerce, a question as old as our Constitution.

This morning, in a joint filing with the State of Montana, Wyoming has asked the Supreme Court of the United States to review the decision by the state of Washington to deny the Millennium Bulk coal terminal permit.

On Martin Luther King Jr. Day we honor the contributions of the great civil rights leader who challenged Americans to live up to the ideals enshrined in our Constitution. I encourage all Wyomingites to embrace his optimism and celebrate his legacy through volunteerism.
I'm pleased that the Senate has approved the #USMCA trade agreement. This is a win for Wyoming's farmers and ranchers and will help boost export sales for businesses in our state.

The  Phase 1 trade agreement with China signed by @POTUS today will benefit Wyoming exporters, including the trona, petroleum and agriculture industries. It also may open doors for Wyoming technology companies to enhance international partnerships.
It was great to chat with @SloanDickey, Dallas Laird and Frank Chapman about the state budget and other topics during a taping of “Report to Wyoming” today.

The U.S. Census Bureau is hiring. Census employees will help ensure a complete, accurate count in Wyoming. This is critical to ensuring our state gets its proper share of federal funding.  #Census2020
